information: In the week ending April 25, 2025, the S&P 500 index rose 4.6% to close at 5,525.21, its best weekly performance of the year to date. The Nasdaq Composite saw a 6.7% increase and the Dow Jones rose 2.5% during the same period. This rally was led by a recovery in large technology stocks. Despite the recent gains, market valuations are elevated, with the price-to-earnings ratio for the S&P 500 cited as being between 19 and 28, above historical averages. The VIX, a measure of market volatility, was recently observed at a high level of approximately 25.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 1 month (until the close on Fri, May 30, 2025)
forecast.status_quo_outcome: Yes — on base rates, monthly S&P 500 closes are higher than the prior month more often than not (~60%), so absent new information, a modestly higher May close is the default.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Inflation prints run hot, pushing Treasury yields higher and pulling down equity multiples; mega-cap earnings/guidance disappoint after the late-April tech-led rebound; volatility (VIX ~25) persists or spikes on macro/geopolitical risk, leading to a late-month drawdown that leaves May’s final close below April’s final close.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Earnings season broadly beats with constructive guidance (especially large-cap tech), inflation data cools or is in line, the Fed sounds patient, and yields stabilize or fall; momentum from late April persists enough to keep May’s month-end close above April’s close even if there are mid-month pullbacks.
forecast.rationale: Base rate: Historically, the S&P 500 finishes up month-over-month roughly 60% of the time. That is my starting point. Research assistant notes: a strong rebound week into Apr 25 (+4.6% S&P; tech-led), but with elevated valuations (P/E cited ~19–28) and a high VIX (~25). Those point to above-average volatility and sensitivity to macro surprises. April’s final close (Apr 30) sets the bar; after a sharp late-April rally, that bar may be relatively high, slightly reducing odds that May ends higher. Offsetting that, momentum and an ongoing earnings season can carry prices if results and guidance are solid. Why not higher than my forecast: Valuations are stretched, volatility is elevated, and the late-April rally raises the hurdle for May’s month-end. A single hot CPI/PCE or yields backup could easily flip the monthly close negative. Why not lower: The status quo tends to be mild monthly gains; the economy and earnings backdrop appear resilient, and tech leadership has reasserted, which often supports follow-through. What would move me up: Softer inflation prints, stable-to-lower long yields, strong mega-cap earnings/guidance, improving breadth, VIX normalizing below ~18, April’s final close not spiking much further (a lower hurdle). What would move me down: Hot inflation or wage data, sharp rise in 10y yields, weak guidance from large tech, renewed geopolitical shocks, breadth deterioration with defensive leadership, or an April month-end surge that sets an even higher bar for May. Netting these, I place modestly-above-coinflip odds on a higher May close versus April.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will the S&P 500 index go up in May 2025?

Question background:
NY Times: [What Is a Bear Market? Are We in One?](https://www.nytimes.com/article/bear-market-stocks-tariffs.html)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question will resolve as Yes if the closing value of the S&P 500 Index on the final trading day of May 2025 is higher than that of the final trading day of April 2025.

The "close" values shown on the [history page of Yahoo finance](https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/%5EGSPC/history?p=%5EGSPC) will be used.


Your research assistant's report says:
In the week ending April 25, 2025, the S&P 500 index rose 4.6% to close at 5,525.21, its best weekly performance of the year to date. The Nasdaq Composite saw a 6.7% increase and the Dow Jones rose 2.5% during the same period. This rally was led by a recovery in large technology stocks. Despite the recent gains, market valuations are elevated, with the price-to-earnings ratio for the S&P 500 cited as being between 19 and 28, above historical averages. The VIX, a measure of market volatility, was recently observed at a high level of approximately 25.

Today is 2025-04-29.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
